column10: b"b' Extended holdReady() to allow the ready event to be re-held after it has already fired'"
b"b' Extended holdReady() to allow the ready event to be re-held after it has already fired. This is incredibly useful for complex AJAX applications
column11: especially when combined with a script loader that uses holdReady. The specific use cases were:1. Add a hold while processing certain types of AJAX response2. Add a hold while the script loader loads any new includes from certain types of AJAX response The result is that the ready event defers as expected for AJAX responses processed this way
column12: opening the door to solve some of the more painful AJAX problems.'"

column10: b"b' Can you show some scenarios where this might be useful
column11: and add it to the 1.7 feature request pile? [pile]url '"

column10: b'b\' Yeah
column11: I\\\'ll give you two answers. First one in code
column12: second one an explanation of the theory behind what we\\\'re doing. It\\\'s a little long
column13: sorry. First
column14: here is my overly simple code example: ===A Script Loader===$.include = function(script){  $.holdReady(true);  add_script_to_document_and_call_function_when_loaded(    script
column15: function(){$.holdReady(false);}  );} ===A Response From The Server===...   $.include("/");  $(function(){    // The expectation is that this code will not be executed until after  has been loaded    $("#widget51").mywidget({foo: "bar"});  });  ... The above works fine so long as this is the original page load (I.E. the ready event hasn\\\'t already fired.) With a vanilla jQuery 1.6 however
column16: it will fail on an ajax request. In other words
column17: the following is likely to give intermittent "mywidget is not a function" errors: $("#content").html($.get("/")); The errors happen because "ready" always lets everything through after the document has loaded
column18: even if  hasn\\\'t downloaded yet. The holdReady() event is ignored in the AJAX case. This is the documented behavior
column19: but it isn\\\'t very helpful. My patch makes this work in both cases
column20: by allowing holdReady() to restart the deferring process at any time. #  The long answer is more about theory and architecture
column21: not just on the client side
column22: but also the server side. There are several competing needs that any web developer usually wants to balance:1. Keeping the code modular. Individual components should be self contained
column23: and should be able to operate without sprinkling dependencies elsewhere.2. Minimizing the number of script files that need to be sucked down for any single request.3. Maximizing the value of the cache for script files.4. Keeping code organized. Separate things in separate files.5. Keeping development easy. "out of flow" things (like having to "rebuild" stuff each time you change a file) are painful. JavaScript isn\\\'t especially well suited to some of these needs. Code organization and the ability to keep server side code modular are especially large problems. Code organization needs generally conflict with minimizing the number of files sucked down. And so on. The dark horse here is actually item 1
column24: modularity. The moment you start mixing your AJAX with any extensive widgetization it comes to bite you HARD. The livequery paradigm is one way people try to solve this
column25: but that has some undesirable traits
column26: and it leaves large portions of the issue unresolved. The largest part of the modularity problem is ensuring that the proper files are available when needed
column27: but no earlier (We don\\\'t want to suck down everything we have
column28: just because an ajax request might return something that needs it.) In the end
column29: for any sort of complex application
column30: a script loader becomes a highly desirable tool. With a good script loader you can ensure that all necessary files are available
column31: while guaranteeing that each file is only loaded a single time (important
column32: since double loading could create bugs). A script loader also opens possibilities for organization of code across separate files
column33: because the files themselves can become responsible for the inclusion of their own external dependencies (Like a WYSIWYG editor
column34: which might require a document range abstraction layer
column38: assuming that we use a script loader
column39: take a look back at the server. A request comes in
column40: and needs to return something: let\\\'s say a complex form with some custom widgets. The view helpers each build a bit of markup for their widgets. Part of the widget markup is a script element that a) uses $.include (our script loader) to guarantee that the required resources are present
column41: and b) uses $(document).ready(function(){...}) to perform any necessary jQuery operations on the newly created widget
column42: once all the resources are known to be present. The desire is for this widget markup to always works exactly the same way
column43: regardless of whether it was used in the initial page load
column44: or in an AJAX request. If we can do that
column45: the other problems are resolved. The relevant script files never have to be included in a large header monolith
column46: so the initial page load is snappy
column47: and the server side code is clean an modular. The cache value is maximized
column48: no script build phase is needed for development
column49: there is no large wasteful collection of livequery declarations because "we need this sometimes". In order for this bit of magic to work though
column50: the $(document).ready() bits in the response have to be able to work AFTER the ready event has already fired once. The nuance here is that in the mind of the typical developer
column51: $(document).ready() doesn\\\'t actually mean "do this when the document has fired it\\\'s on load event". The native load event is such a mess
column52: nobody wants to think about it anymore. That\\\'s why jQuery wraps it up in a neat little package. Now we just dump everything in $(document).ready()
column54: we mean "do this as soon as it is safe to run my stuff." The fact that the server responded with new script requirements that have not been loaded
column55: means that it is no longer "ready" or "safe" to execute new scripts
column56: until after it resolves those requirements. The script loader calls $.holdReady(true)
column57: just as it does when loading scripts during the page load. The only difference now is that it was an AJAX request
column60: the developer doesn\\\'t want to have to care. The intent is still the same: "do this stuff whenever it is safe". The expectation is that execution of any $(document).ready() blocks will always be delayed as appropriate. Once the requirements are loaded
column61: execution continues. This change makes robust script loaders possible
column62: and clears the path for web development paradigms that blur the lines between AJAX and page loads (making the ajaxification of previously static web apps almost trivial.) Without this
column64: because it can\\\'t be safely and easily used with AJAX (a major use case). The addition of holdReady() in 1.6 is a major step in the right direction
column65: and this patch continues that by moving it into the AJAX realm.\''

column10: b'b\' The argumentation pro holdReady are so wrong on so many levels. ## this breaks code independance There is nothing modular about having a script loader delaying the ready event: on the contrary
column11: you give any module in your application the means to derail the semantics of the dom ready event and take the risk of breaking other portions of your app relying on said event. In your very sample module
column12: if the ajax request fails
column13: then all modules that rely on dom readyness and are loaded after said module (or even before if dom readyness hasn\\\'t been notified yet) will just plain stop working. Now that\\\'s modularity for you! That\\\'s how dangerous
column14: inconsistent and pointless this "feature" is. It makes non-dependant modules loading order important while it shouldn\\\'t be: you don\\\'t always load interdependant modules
column15: sometimes you do have separate and independant portions in your app (at least if you\\\'re not doing it wrong). If some remote resource is temporarily unavailable
column16: say the Twitter Data API you only use for a little tweeting widget in the sidebar
column17: do you really want your page as a whole to become unusable because no dom readyness bound function will be called? Is this really the kind of approach we want to promote? ## we\\\'re breaking jQuery for "convenience"
column18: promoting bad practice in the process Having a bunch of "master" scripts that will block any other module from being loaded should be done within the script loaders themselves. Let them provide a means to add a "global" script and not load  execute modules before those "master" scripts are loaded. Is it so hard to code that we need to break jQuery for this? Why should other code in the page that do not make use of the script loader be penalized or plain broken to save a few bytes in the script loader? Beside
column19: how do I go about making jQuery itself a global include
column20: seeing as I obviously don\\\'t have holdReady available at that point? Make an incantation? Nope
column21: you have to use a script tag for this
column22: just as you should for any global script in your app. If you truly want a script to become "part of the environment" (like the script loader itself btw)
column23: then that\\\'s the way to go. It\\\'s easy enough to check script tags in your  server-side when running your build script that will deliver this fancy all-in-one-file minified js. Even worse
column24: how can one promote "global" scripts includes as "more modular" or "better organized". Take nodejs
column25: for instance: in every single js file
column26: you **have** to require all the libs you use in your file. Nobody\\\'s complaining about it because it actually makes sense. Global includes are frown upon in any environment I know of and for good reason (they\\\'re only available using command-line arguments for the compilers of all languages I used so far
column27: that should tell people something). Having to specify all you dependencies for a module is not an inconvenience
column28: it\\\'s what makes your system truly modular in the first place: you can take your module as is and drop it into any other  and it\\\'ll just work. If you use "global includes"
column29: then you have to copy parts of the environment configuration with it. Talk about maintenance hell. ## it makes jQuery\\\'s dom readyness notification unreliable The dom ready event has specific semantics and is **not** some kind of synchronization utility to be meddled with just because it\\\'s convenient to a niche. I\\\'m appalled enough that we have holdReady in the first place... but that we try and break things even more by making it work post dom readyness is beyond me. This has bad practice painted all over the place for reasons I already explained before. With holdReady in place
column31: as a  developper cannot trust jQuery to properly notify dom readyness. So
column33: I\\\'ll duplicate the dom readyness logic in my own code and never use the $( fn ) signature ever again since any third party can meddle with its behaviour without my knowledge. We\\\'re talking self-deprecation here. ## you can easily join one or several ajax requests with dom readyness I also don\\\'t understand why some people keep on implying it\\\'s difficult to sync on ajax requests **and** dom readyness
column34: all you need is a dom readyness Promise and a construct as follows: Funily enough

column11: This really isn\\\'t the place to start a fight over whether holdReady() itself is an acceptable feature. holdReady is here
column12: and there are a handful of very important use cases for it. Before holdReady was added
column13: it really wasn\\\'t possible to write a decent script loader without hacking the core. (By "decent" I mean one that would allow you to replace every script tag with a call to the script loader
column14: and have everything continue to work like it did before.) Some quick thoughts on some of your specific complaints: **Code Independence**: In a vanilla web page everything already has to wait for every script file to be sucked down and processed
column15: regardless of which snippets require which scripts. This isn\\\'t any different. **Nothing modular about...**: Modularity comes (in part) from being able to delay loading of secondary scripts until they are actually needed
column16: avoiding minified monoliths. The modularity empowered by this is on the _server_ side
column17: not the client side. **Failed AJAX Request example**: This is a bug in your theoretical code
column18: not a problem with the holdReady concept. Correctly written code would use the completed  success+error callback(s) to clear the hold. Additionally
column19: someone would have to be soft in the head to hold the ready event just because they are waiting for data from Twitter. That\\\'s not what this is for. **"Let [the script loaders] provide a means to add a "global" script"**: This isn\\\'t DRY. Any time you are waiting for the document to have been loaded
column20: you pretty much need to have assurances that the scripts are ready. The generic dom ready event was originally designed to give this assurance
column21: holdReady allows script loaders to continue to offer that assurance
column22: even though the internal dom ready event hangs you out to dry when a script loader is used. **"you should [use a script tag] for any global script in your app"**: Um. Wow. You really have no idea why a script loader would ever be needed
column23: do you? I\\\'m not entirely sure how to respond to this. Do you do server side development? PHP? Imagine what it would be like to develop a complex application if PHP didn\\\'t have an include or require
column24: or if  didn\\\'t wait for the file to be included before continuing execution. **"fancy all-in-one-file minified js"**: I reject the fancy all-in-one minified js. Although this is better than serially loading individual files
column25: it is far from ideal. You are delaying the first page load to suck down every drop of script that the application will ever have to use
column26: even though 90% of it won\\\'t get used at all (or at least not until much later). Complex systems will have _worse_ page load times site wide due to the massive amount of script that has to be processed on every page load
column27: even though it isn\\\'t needed. A good script loader offers much better alternatives. **"it makes jQuery\\\'s dom readyness notification unreliable"**: It never was "reliable". If you use $(fn) after dom ready has fired
column29: even though dom ready is not firing at that moment. If you **really** need the dom ready event
column30: bind directly to the dom ready event at the low level. It is highly unlikely that you will ever actually need this
column32: you have options. **"any third party can meddle with its behaviour without my knowledge"**: Not every developer is a raging idiot
column34: you don\\\'t want their code on your site for reasons that go far beyond whether they abused holdReady. If you are really that worried about it
column35: you could add to your code. **"you can easily join one or several ajax requests with dom readyness"**: Your proposed code doesn\\\'t solve remotely the same problem. Look at this again after you start lusting for a good script loader

column11: I understand your concern with the possibility of not staying ready. I guess that is sort of my point. The developer has been made two conflicting promises. The first is that "inside $.ready
column12: all scripts are loaded" (this is implicit in the dom ready event
column13: or enforced via $.holdReady by a compatible script loader). The second is that "$.ready stays ready"
column14: which is part of the purpose of the abstraction. This is fine until $.require gets called later; then you have a conflict. Do you continue to run $.ready callbacks
column15: even though some scripts are now not loaded? Or do you wait for the new scripts to load before continuing? My vote is for the latter
column16: because it honors the spirit of both needs. The developer who uses $.ready(...) has already explicitly decided to run the script later if needed
column17: to ensure that everything is ready before the script runs. The developer still has a guarantee that the script will always run
column18: and also has the guarantee that any previously included scripts were loaded. @rwldrn
column19: The need for pausing the ready event after a completed load isn\\\'t obvious until you consider the server side. You mentioned seeking "well known implementations with proven use cases"
column20: so I\\\'ll use Zend Framework to describe the situation.1. Consider a Zend Framework based app2. Include jQuery (but not jQuery UI) on the page3. $.load a view that uses one of the jQuery view helpers4. It won\\\'t work. These helpers manage their own dependencies
column21: and will attempt to add the needed script

b"b' 1.8 effects'"

b'b\' So I don\\\'t feel like this branch is by any means DONE... I just want an easy way for people to look at what I\\\'m doing and discuss it. It currently passes all jQuery core unit tests in chrome so I figure its time to share it on a wider scale.  It currently weighs in around 150 bytes more than the current core after min and gzip.# jQuery 1.8 Effects To quote my own summary from an email thread:## General organization is a new function which implements most of what our current function hiding inside currently does.  It returns an animation object which has the standard promise methods ( and ) plus a helper called to publish its state information to the outside world. functions will be called with a boolean whenever someone  s the animation. functions will NOT be called on but will be called whenever the animation comes to its natural completion.  functions will be called whenever the animation completes regardless of it had been  ed. is very similar to the old (so much so that it is being used as such for backwards-compat).  It handles the actual  operations for a single element and property from 0% to 100%.  Animations contain an array of Tweens that will be updated when their function is called.## New hook points### Pre-filters allow a plugin to look at the and of an animation being created and overide some default functionality
column11: or do something else entirely with it. The hide / show special case preFilter in the code is a good example.  It creates its own tweens for the hide and show scope to retain access to in the callbacks it attaches to hook all of timmy\\\'s goodness together.  Pre-filters are allowed to return their own object so long as it implements
column12: and  . will be none the wiser.### Allows you to peek at the  combinations and decide how to create a tween for that property or value.  It should return truthy if it created the tween.  If you want the tween to be managed by the animation you should use the helper
column13: or push your own object containing a function to array.### A hook point for individual properties with a that uses and  ## Current IssuesThe "special easing" code right now bugs me because it really should run before the  preFilter
column14: but since makes it basically impossible to accept an array as a possible animated property value
column15: anyone wanting an array value will have to prepend to the preFilter perhaps not such a bad thing...I have not yet tested this code for performance or potential memory leaks.Should be to be in line with the example set by ajax: [ ]url I would like to avoid making it so makes more sense to me...\''

b'b" [1.9] Prevent Clearing Cloned Style to Affect Source Element\'s Style. Fixes #8908"'

b'b" # Clearing a Cloned Element\'s Style Causes the Original Element\'s Style to be Cleared## Introduction In IE9 and IE10 you can run into the situation when clearing ( ) a cloned element\'s style will also clear out the original element\'s corresponding style. The actual [jQuery Core Ticket #8908]url  isolates the bug when using the background-image style.  While I was trying to recreate and research this issue I had a feeling that there may be other styles that have the same issue
column11: so I\'ve created a [test suite]url  checking [252 CSS1-3 styles]url  and testing various assertions.  Along the way
column12: I also found some additional inconsistencies. These findings are technically unrelated to the #8908 issue so I will list those inconsistencies somewhere else and we can discuss those later.### Source Element\'s Style Cleared When Cloned Element\'s Style Cleared### IE9 & IE10 After testing 252 various styles only the following 8 ended up being problematic.background-attachmentbackground-colorbackground-imagebackground-positionbackground-repeatbackground-clipbackground-originbackground-size### IE 6/7/8
column13: Chrome
column14: Firefox
column15: Opera Thankfully these browsers did not have the problem described in this issue when tested.## Proposed Solutions### 1. Use Default Values when Trying to Empty Style The following fix resolves the weird issue by substituting and empty string with it\'s default value. An object is used to store the style name and associated default value. If the value happens to be an empty string then it will look in the object for a matching key and if there is a match it will use that instead. #### ProsThis is very explicit in describing which styles are problematic in IE#### ConsThere is extra code executed when clearing the style for a nonIE browser. This could be a problem because updating a style via the method is very commonThere is a considerable amount of code to account for all problematic styles and this will bloat the jQuery source### 2. Strange Side Effect That Breaks the Clone Connection This solution is a little more strange and not so obvious. I ran into this fix as I was building up my unit tests and asserting a bunch of things I thought should be true. One of those assertions was verifying that when setting a style using the method that it actually worked. So
column16: I used the getter (  method
column17: but by doing so I found the problem going away just by calling the getter! And with that the following solution came about. You may notice a slightly strange piece of code
column18: but that was needed to get around an Opera bug I had when working with XML nodes. Technically I could have made the whole fix into one statement
column19: but the minification process does a decent job of squishing down the fix to look like  .   #### ProsThe amount of code for this fix is relatively smallThis code is limited to the clone execution path
column20: which happens infrequently when compared to the method approach in option #1.#### ConsThis relies on a weird quirk in IE9/10 to get around the problem
column21: but it seems to be the most succinct. ### 3. Have IE9 & IE10 Fix this Bug It would be ideal if no patch had to be made to jQuery at all and IE9 and IE10 could apply a fix instead. Seeing that the issue is found in IE9 though may rule out this option entirely. #### ProsNo patch for jQuery would be needed#### ConsEven if the bug was fixed immediately for IE9 & IE10 there would still be an issue with versions of IE9 that didn\'t have the IE fix.## Unit Test The following Unit Test exposes the problem in IE9 and IE10. In browsers that don\'t support these styles I am skipping over them and asserting that they are not an issue. ## Conclusion Based on the research I have done testing 252 CSS styles I have isolated this issue to only 8 styles in IE9 and IE10.  I\'ve recommended solving this issue 3 different ways
column22: but in the end _the 2nd option seems best to me_ since it only is executed in the clone execution path and is significantly smaller than the 1st option. The 3rd option of having IE fix this issue seems too late since the issue also affects IE9."'

column10: b'b" # Changes Since the Initial Pull Request ## Source Code Changes I make a new test in the support module called that is if the browser clears only the clone\'s style appropriate
column11: but is if it incorrectly clear\'s the original element\'s style as IE9 and IE10 do with 8 different styles. I picked the shortest style name of the 8 to test to keep the code short. The feature test intentionally doesn\'t use jQuery in order to keep the test as fast as possible.   I am using the property in the fix right before the clone in   As I was retesting the code in IE6/7/8/9/10 I noticed that one of the styles ( ) was not passing in IE9 :( The weird call fixed all of the 8 broken styles in IE10
column12: but only 7 of them in IE9. So
column13: I had to add the following code in the method of the file to fix that outlier. ## Browsers Tested I have run the above changes through the following browsers ## WindowsChrome 22Firefox 15.0IE 10/9/8/7/6Opera 12.5Safari 5.1/5.0/4.0 ## MacChrome 20.0Firefox 14.0Opera 12/11.6/11.1Safari 5.1/5.0/4.0 ## Unit Test Changes As I was testing the code in all the above browsers I added another assertion to the Unit Test to check if the style that was being cleared on the clone element was indeed being reset. Because of that addition assertion I made the following changes...Added a unit test to verify that the clone was indeed reset correctlyAdd the value to match the backgroundColor for Opera 11.1When a background-image is cleared in Firefox it sets the value to the full image path that it is inheriting Added the value to match the backgroundPosition for Firefox 5.0Switched background-clip to because Safari 5.0 doesn\'t support that value  # Summary of ChangesI added the check and used it before the to limit when a call to occurs (IE9 / 10)I had to add another fix in the method to fix the style that wasn\'t fixed by the above. This code path is also limited by the check.I added another assertion to the Unit Test to verify that clearing out the style indeed resets it to an expected default value."'

column10: b'b\' @wwalser the remark shouldn\\\'t be taken literally. What I\\\'m saying is that
column11: when you cannot even trust standard methods to be implemented correctly
column12: you\\\'re probably better off not making any inference in your code
column13: period. It\\\'s not about the browsers that jQuery supports today
column14: it\\\'s about the ones it will have to support tomorrow (FF & Chrome are very aggressive and very breaking in that department). Everytime we release a new version
column15: we hope for it to be the latest in it\\\'s 1.x branch. If such is the case
column16: then some sites will have this version for a looooong time (1.4.4 anyone?). Now
column17: comes along a browser that does break a single assumption... Feature detection should be as bullet proof as humanly possible (as in testing for the exact blank the workaround is supposed to fill)
column18: feature inference should be avoided at all cost
column19: since it doesn\\\'t test for the blank itself and
column20: thus
column21: is just browser sniffing in disguise
column22: even if it actually sniffs a large range of browsers: "this is true
column23: and in every browser I know I can deduce this totally unrelated thing is true too so it will always be true no matter what". I find it sad that we could actually feature detect here but just refuse to do so because "we know of no browser that would break the assumption" or "it saves 4 bytes". That doesn\\\'t sit well with me regarding how jQuery is supposed to endure a little past the few browser versions it supports right this instant. And I _know_ we cannot safeguard against all future bugs
column24: but I sure hope we can properly handle the ones we fix today so that the code is adapted to variations on the same theme. I hope I made my reasoning a little clearer.\''

column11: so this was not that simple. I did not implement the proper tests at the beginning and afterwards I found out what was the real problem. The point is IE6-8 do not "properly" parse param elements without a name attribute ( with a non empty string value ).And this "could make sense" taking into account the HTML 4.01 specs: url  where the name attribute: name    CDATA    #REQUIRED -property name -So  = "<param type=\\\'foo\\\' />"; does generate a HTMLUnknownElement as the div childNodebut  = "<param type=\\\'foo\\\'  name=\\\'bar\\\' />"; works as expected I haven\\\'t found a really elegant solution to this issue
column12: but checking for param elements and inserting a dummy name attr in case is not there.  And I don\\\'t even know if it\\\'s worthwhile fixing this IE behaviour. I hope this is useful.\''

column12: they should not test more than what they are supposed to test (and

column15: then you test a whole bunch of the internals of each time you wanna test something completely unrelated (headers). You created a hidden dependency in the javascript unit test because of some logic in PHP. That\\\'s why I started the rewrite: things had gone very wrong because too big a proportion of the logic of our ajax tests was taking place in PHP due to "magical" scripts that would do one thing or another
column16: implicit changes to the response given an unrelated parameter. They created hidden dependencies _client-side_
column17: they were also hidding actual problems in our unit tests. The fact we had a lot of PHP scripts that served no purpose is one thing and good riddance. But the goal here is to empower our javascript unit tests and give them power over the whole client-server cycle. Implicit logic server-side like changing the content type because headers are supposed to be set is a no-go. I\\\'m guessing the actual reason you\\\'re doing so is because it makes it simpler to test for the results using deepEqual: if so create a helper client-side that does the parsing / test but keep the content type alone

b'b\' Sugar url  adds methods to built-in prototypes. Now
column11: I realize that sentence alone will likely elicit a strong reaction
column12: especially within the jQuery team. However
column13: Sugar makes an argument that there is a safe way to augment JS natives by being safe
column14: conservative in approach
column15: tons of testing
column16: and a few fundamental differences to Prototype (most of this is detailed here url  Sugar takes a certain stance
column17: but I do see valid points to both sides of the argument. However
column18: I believe that the pull request I have submitted
column19: lies _outside_ this argument. The crux of the issue is that jQuery is checking for the property on an object that is assumed to be a but in fact may also be a string. When making this assumption it should do a type check to ensure that the object is an instance of before assuming the property on it. I am anticipating a counterpoint that "it is reasonable for libs to assume "clean" prototypes" and I think there is a valid point to be made there. However I have my own counterpoints to that
column20: and regardless this change can only serve to make jQuery more robust. Also I believe that if you are presuming a property it is reasonable to assume it to be scoped to the object you have defined it on. I am probably going to remove this method from Sugar anyway
column21: 1. as an emergency fix on the assumption that this pr will take a while to be released even if it is accepted and 2. because it never fit into the lib very well anyway. Thank you! \''

column10: b"b' #13355 Uglifyjs compression options and variable sequence optimization '"
b'b" Some Uglifyjs options might work great for minification
column11: but worsens gzip size
column12: disabling these options will increase minified size but decrease gzipped one
column13: Sometimes changing sequence of variables initialization might save couple of bytes in gzipped size
column14: in this PR
column15: i also propose find optimal sequences of those variables that don\'t have an assigment. I did it with limitation of 7 items in sequence
column16: i.e. here is 11 variables with undefined as initialization value
column17: so all possible permutations for variables without an assigment is 39916800
column18: i checked only 5040 of them.  Same optimizations could be applied to 2.0 source and for variables with (re)assigment but i did not finish AST analysis for those possibilities. Anyway
column19: 1.9 current gzipped size is 33006 bytes
column20: in this branch it\'s 32642
column21: all and all it\'s -346 bytes for gzipped size."'

b'b" I don\'t want to spoil the party and I appreciate the enormous (ENORMOUS) work involved but I think we\'re going way overboard here:managing the order of variables is absolutely unmaintainable so the first patch we add
column11: boom
column12: +70bytes  for no apparent reason
column13: the order of variable declarations sometimes have a meaning
column14: for instance
column15: some vars are grouped to make logical sense in parts of the code. Do we really want to make the code more difficult to ?How aggressively is the minified version size augmented by this ? Everyone is not using gzip. I\'d love to have stats that actually establishes the majority does. Also
column16: the augmentation of the minified size would be nice to have. Like @gibson042
column17: I toyed with the order of var decls in files to see huge change in  size. However I always thought the process of re-ordering the var decls without assignments should be automatized. Let a tool handle this and we won\'t have to think about it or wonder if we found the best permutations. Problem is there are 39916800 permutations as @orkel pointed out
column18: so it would mean uglyfying 39916800 to find the best. One could argue euristics could be found
column19: but even ordering by number of occurences of the variables in the code is not good: it\'s all about repeating patterns throughout the file so it\'s about naming variables so that the same code appears throughout various . So I seriously doubt the approach is feasible anyway. Maybe we can lax some uglify js rules so that it gzips better but re-ordering variables like this is non-sense. It is an incredibly costly 1.05% saving in regard to maintenance and readability costs."'

column10: b'b" I\'m not that worried @jaubourg. It\'s like cleaning the bathroom. You know it will get dirty again
column11: and that you can\'t clean it perfectly
column12: but that shouldn\'t stop you from trying to clean it. It would be great if Uglify had some knowedge of gzip so that it could optimize the variable name order and length
column13: maybe we can talk @mishoo into it. "'

column10: b'b" Except it does make it messier from a maintenance point of view. It\'s not about cleaning it\'s about re-arranging the dirt so that the help (uglify) can clean better. Re-ordering var decls and separating related decls (as is particularly evident in  ) makes it much more difficult to maintain and fix stuff. We\'re going overboard here. That\'s definitely not something we wanna do manually. There\'s a reason why it hasn\'t been done already which makes it more than likely that it won\'t be done again. It\'s a hella lot of work that disrupts the natural reading of the unminified code and needs constant re-adjustements. Putting decls without init value on top was already a stretch (but something easy to maintain so the trade-off was ok). All this work and disruption for 1%? And again
column11: what is the size increase minified NOT gzipped?"'

column10: b"b' There is no additional ongoing maintenance burden introduced by this pull request. I want to make it clear
column11: there is no new requirement that future pull requests and patches be processed through all these permutations to minimize their size. Pull requests should not be rearranging unrelated parts of a file in order to keep the size of the particular patch smaller than it would otherwise be. That just clutters the diffs and makes them harder to follow. The reason I like this pull request is precisely because its purpose is clear and singular. And again
column12: it does not create any future obligations
column13: period.'"

column10: b'b\' Yes
column11: PRs shouldn\\\'t re-arrange unrelated parts of a file in order to keep the size small. Because it\\\'s disruptive and borks existing code. Apply this kind of patch JUST before a release and revert it JUST after if you want the byte savings. But changing code "for real" for a temporal gain makes absolutely no sense. This IS a disrupting patch that changes the natural reading of code throughout the entire code base
column12: yet will progressively lose the gain as the code is reworked. So you\\\'re changing code across the board
column13: making it harder to  (it\\\'s about having stuff in a meaningful order
column14: not about having to re-order all the time
column15: btw)
column16: for 346 bytes you\\\'ll lose at the first patch declaring variables? Is this for real? And we still don\\\'t have the impact on non-gzipped minified which is most probably the most commonly used version of jQuery? Are we that desperate to look good on the front page of our site?\''

column10: b'b" I don\'t find it to make the code harder to read. In fact I think you would be hard-pressed to know this patch was applied at all. Yes
column11: there is the chance we\'ll lose some or perhaps even all the gains over time
column12: don\'t worry about it. Just like cleaning the bathroom: Go in
column13: do your business
column14: and leave."'

column11: in Chrome.'"

column10: b'b" Resolves this bug:  Modern browsers & IE9+ offer a native attribute for updating a DOM element\'s inner text. It\'s named  . By updating this directly
column11: we can avoid creating two new DOM nodes per text value update. This removes a memory leak. :) (IE8 and lower continue to work as before.) Note: All tests are passing
column12: but no tests were added. This is because JavaScript doesn\'t have access to DOM node counts. However
column13: we can verify the value added fairly easily. Step 1: Learn how to record memory usage over time (10s or so)
column14: with Chrome Dev Tools.url  Step 2: Contrast these two Fiddles. Pay attention to the climbing DOM Node Count in the second example.url  # new optimizationurl  # current implementation Also
column15: it turns out Zepto is already using this optimization. Though they don\'t provide a fallback for IE8 and lower. Feel free to ask any questions. And props to @Sysaninster for getting this started!"'

column10: b"b' From my understanding at the moment jQuery does not explicitly follow semver (in 1.x & 2.x land) the bump to 3.0 is starting point of official semver support and since 3.0 is a major bump breaking changes can be introduced.WeakMaps are available in all modern browsers but are kind of painful at the moment. column14: less common elements that this also happens to._ jQuery is not selecting those blank-prefixed elements when there\\\'s a multi-stage (combo) selector.  It works with and using the tagname without the prefix
column15: but not when using a selector pattern like  .  Refer to the example below
column16: for a clearer understanding. _Affected Browsers: I only know this applies to IE8.  I\\\'m doubtful that it applies to other versions of IE
column17: but I\\\'m not able to test._ -### Update My statement above isn\\\'t exactly correct; doesn\\\'t necessarily solve the issue.  You\\\'ll notice inconsistent behavior when you use pseudo-selectors
column18: such as  .  The demo shows that the IE8 bug (prefixed colon) is not handled using jQuery
column19: and using pseudo-selectors should at least be consistent with selecting by element tagname (whether it includes the prefixed elements
column20: or not).  That is and should return the same results
column21: if there are no hidden  . The behavior I found in IE8 is that acts like  .  What I\\\'m after is something to patch the IE prefix bug so that acts like  . -### Demo / Test Case url url (for IE8 testing)  \''

column10: b"b' Fixed by 5c4be05d3b32456553dc944853b77fa96ae8b2b8'"
b"b' Please provide a function for escaping special characters in selectors'"
b'b" Originally reported by fejesjoco at: url  I read this article:  url  .  It says plain and simple that a colon and a period must be escaped. And then the example code also escapes square brackets
column11: so there\'s a problem already. In the future
column12: you may add a new special character for a cool new selector feature
column13: and that will be a breaking change.  I can see already how many bugs have been filed about special characters in selectors and then closed as being documented. I understand it completely. This is not a bug report
column14: this is a feature request.  Please provide a function for escaping special characters in selectors. Benefits: it\'s a very easy utility function to implement and useful in many casesall those people who never cared about such issues
column15: will realize they should use this escaping mechanismall those people who used to run into problems with special characters before
column16: used to file all those unnecessary bugs
column17: now they will have an out-of-the-box solution insteadif a spec changes or jQuery API changes
column18: it won\'t be a breaking change because the updated escape function would handle the new cases toothe quoted documentation suggests to copy-paste some code into my own JS
column19: but jQuery is about helping eliminate those kinds of code pieces
column20: it would be great to have it embedded I also realized there are much more characters which could need escaping if we\'re not just talking about the restricted ID\'s:  url  . This proposed escape function could handle that as well. I hope it\'s not a problem if it unnecessarily escapes characters in a selector in cases when it\'s not needed.Issue reported for jQuery 1.10.2"'

column10: b"b' **Comment author: ** This issue came up on the WHATWG mailing list a few months ago:  url  and was added to CSSOM:  url  '"
b'b" **Comment author: fejesjoco** I\'m glad it\'s being worked on. Do you think it would be reasonable to provide that function in jQuery
column11: and that would call () if it\'s available
column12: or use a fixed regexp if it\'s not? I look at jQuery as a layer that
column13: among others
column14: hides those kinds of browser differences. Also
column15: () is only a valid alternative as long as jQuery\'s syntax is in accordance with CSS
column16: but jQuery can actually extend that syntax. jQuery has lots and lots of functions that depend on selectors
column17: so I believe there would be a real place for this utility method. "'

column10: b"b' **Comment author: ** jQuery allows for additional selectors
column11: but not for additional syntax. I believe there should never be a case where a proper CSS escaping method would fail on a custom jQuery selector. '"

column10: b'b" **Comment author: timmywil** There are certainly helpful use cases. The most common case I foresee is concatenating an attribute value in an attribute selector. Certain special characters have meaning in selectors unless they are escaped
column11: so it is impossible to predict the user\'s intentions 100% of the time
column12: which means inevitable non-bug reports as well.  I\'m inclined to vote against the feature not because of a lack of utility externally
column13: but because we have no need of it internally
column14: which is usually the formula for a great plugin. "'

column10: b'b" **Comment author: dmethvin** Since it\'s being addressed by standards
column11: I don\'t know that we want to get out ahead of that. We could possibly offer a wrapper
column12: but it seems like someone who wanted this functionality could just as easily create a polyfill. So I\'m not a big fan either. I don\'t know how it complicates things but $( str ) could also be HTML or a script
column13: not just a selector. Not sure whether a script injection attempt via a CSS fragment could be made to succeed.  Marking this open for discussion at the meeting next month. "'

column10: b'b\' **Comment author: fejesjoco** $(str) is not a use case I was thinking about. The use case is when I want to add some variable string into a selector
column11: without breaking the selector. For example
column12: this is broken for parameters like "a.b": function getElementById2(id) {  return $("#" + id);} I should write this instead: function getElementById2(id) {  return $("#" + $.selectorescape(id));} There could be many such vulnerabilities out there like that already. For example
column13: this was just fixed in  MVC here:  url  . They added their own escape mechanism for 4 metacharacters .:[]
column14: I don\\\'t know if its enough or not
column15: and who knows what some other people might think what should be escaped.  It makes sense to me that the question "hey
column16: mr. interpreter
column17: which characters should I escape for you?" can be best answered by the interpreter itself. A good example of that is the regex escaping in .NET:  url  . It knows what the special characters are and how they should be escaped
column18: so you can put user-supplied strings into a regexp without worrying about anything. \''

column10: b"b' **Comment author: dmethvin** See also #11773. Parts of a built-up str may need to be selector-escaped or html-escaped before being passed to $(str) depending on its purpose and origin.  '"
b'b\' **Comment author: fejesjoco** Yes
column11: it\\\'s a similar problem. Every time when an engine supports certain magic characters
column12: the user may accidentally submit a string which does something else than intended. Also the engine has no way to know what\\\'s intentional and what\\\'s not. The best solution is if the engine itself provides a proper escaping function. The engine knows what to escape
column13: the user only has to know to call it for string parts where no special interpretation is intended. These functions are way too simple to put into plugins
column14: and they should be the integral parts of the interpreting engines because the rules may change over time. I should be able to do $(whatever).html("<p>" + htmlescape(whatever) + "</p>") or $("#" + cssescape())
column15: etc. \''

column10: b'b" **Comment author: fejesjoco** Found a similar thing: $. It could also be added to be available globally. It\'s not strictly jQuery related
column11: but it\'s already there in jQuery UI (in a very wrong place) and it has a use-case. Since core JavaScript provides RegExp
column12: of course it should also provide its own escaping function
column13: but it doesn\'t.  Here\'s a very good example. I may want to find whole words that the user specifies like this: new RegExp(\'(^|[^\\\\w])\' + user_supplied_value + \'($|[^\\\\w])\'). The user supplied value should be properly escaped so that it doesn\'t contain any characters which are handled specially in a regexp. "'

b"b' jquery CORS based ajax request fails with zombiejs'"
b'b\' I have already posted an issue around this on the zombie boards: url  When using regular xhr (granted its not cross browser etc) it works as expected
column11: however when using jquery ajax it blows up with "no transport"
column12: which when traced through seems to be thrown at: url  line 621 I am not sure if this is because zombiejs apparently ignores pre-flights (no documentation on it)
column13: or if it is something else
column14: but I have got a reproduction scenario on cloud9. url  If you log in there will be 3 parts to it: 1) The nodejs server which provides CORS responses2) A jquery client page
column15: an XHR client page3) A zombie test which runs both scenarios The XHR scenario works as expected and returns "success"
column16: the jquery one blows up with "no transport". Both client pages work fine through a browser (chrome latest) but I do not know what jquery is attempting to do under the hood when it does its invocation.\''

column10: b'b" We have never tested with zombiejs and don\'t support it
column11: so if it doesn\'t behave like a browser it wouldn\'t be surprising. jQuery can only use the XHR transport on cross-domain requests if the object indicates that it supports CORS.  Just a guess
column12: but perhaps you need to set to indicate the zombiejs fake XHR object supports CORS if it doesn\'t have  ? Really you should triage this with zombiejs until you determine what it is they do that isn\'t browser-like. I\'ll close this ticket in the meantime and we can reopen if there\'s something that needs to be done."'

column10: b"b' Well I have listed the original issue that was raised on the zombie board
column11: so you have that. I have also got a reproduction scenario which shows it working with a normal xhr object but not working with jquery ajax. I have just tried the explicit and that seems to have fixed it
column12: what does that actually do behind the scenes as there is not much information as to what setting and not setting the cors based options actually does.'"

column10: b"b' A standard XHR object will have a property indicating it can perform CORS. If this is missing but the XHR can still perform cross-domain requests
column11: setting can override. This is most common in situations such as  where cross-domain restrictions are not enforced. Sounds like things are sorted as far as jQuery goes.'"

column10: b'b\' Standardize "invalid input" behavior\''
b"b' Many jQuery collection operations are only meaningful on elements or (somewhat less commonly) DOM nodes
column11: but the collections can logically contain _anything_. Such operations should **always** assume valid input
column12: potentially throwing exceptions when they encounter an invalid member\\xe2\\x80\\x94especially given the ease of manually cleaning like  .Single-member read (e.g.
column15: )Whole-collection read (e.g.
column16: )Whole-collection write (e.g.
column20: ) Special consideration is warranted for single-member reads responding to empty collections. Current behavior usually returns
column21: which seems reasonable to standardize on (including changing those methods that return
column22: like and  ). There are cases where this collides with real output
column23: but such collisions seem to be sane\\xe2\\x80\\x94
column26: etc. Related:#2114#2115'"

column10: b'b" Per today\'s meeting

column10: b'b" I think we all agree here
column11: but we\'ll need to address each change on a case-by-case basis and assess its impact on the community. Rather than making sweeping changes across the board and asking everyone to make lots of adjustments to their code
column12: we\'re going to do this incrementally
column13: in stages. The niche use cases can be done first with a few of the more common cases being introduced every major release. We already have some changes in the pipeline. For any other changes
column14: let\'s have specific issues opened for each one. I\'m closing this issue because we\'ve reached a consensus and now it\'s too broad."'

The className and classList IDL attributes, defined in the DOM specification, reflect the class content attribute.". Now, people might ask for "please use createElementNS() depending on context" or something, which could incur  costs, but the class API issue is pretty easy to fix, just a series of 1 line changes to swap className for  (and adding SVG cases for the class API tests).\''

jquery	2199	closed	19	timmywil	2015-04-11 18:59:57	92.58		+1		b'b" The change is simple enough that we probably won\'t hurt performance, size, or simplicity. I\'ve wanted this myself in the past. My concern is that users will want SVG supported across the board and that is not going to happen (so I\'d just as soon leave SVG on the wontfix list). jQuery will remain a HTML DOM library and leave the hard parts of working with SVG elements to libraries that focus on that. That said, the ability to work with classes in SVG is a minor utility that could provide disproportional benefits to users that don\'t need anything but class manipulation, which I would imagine happens pretty often."'

column10: b'b" Is this in response to #2094? The logic in this patch is wrong. it is dropping out of the dispatch loop if someone deletes one handler
column11: even if there are more handlers on the list. The unit tests you added aren\'t complete enough to catch that. From a performance standpoint
column12: this is putting a lot of overhead on the dispatch code. If there are N handlers for an element we now traverse the handler list up to N-squared times inside the dispatcher via  . Although we might be able to use that in master
column13: we\'d need to use in compat
column14: which would be even slower. In #2094 we resolved to just document this because it was such a rare edge case. If there was a simple way to push the overhead to where we\'d rarely see it
column15: we could fix it but I think that would involve exposing the dispatcher\'s handler list (or a deletion method). It doesn\'t seem worth the complexity to me but maybe there\'s a simpler solution I haven\'t seen. As far as the CLA
column16: be sure that your name and email on the CLA exactly match the one you used for your commits and it should work on your next commit."'

b'b" # Issue This issue is present in both version 1 and 2 of jQuery. It is happening on inline elements wrapping block elements
column11: which is valid in HTML5
column12: such as a header and an image wrapped in a single anchor. Two issues arise:1. Different browsers report  of the anchor differently. For example Firefox would report one visible anchor in the example below
column13: and Chrome will report 0. This also highly depends on the CSS styles applied
column14: as on the page where this issue was discovered missing images are not displayed at all instead of the common missing image icon.2. While a browser may report an anchor as invisible
column15: child elements are still visible and clickable as they inherit anchor properties.## Example  # Solution There are 2 potential solutions that come to mind
column16: but each has flaws1. Loop through child elements and check each for visibility. Potentially harmful for performance
column17: although the selector is already marked as such in the documentation. 2. Check parent for visibility. Probably not enough on its own
column18: as it will report incorrectly
column19: if anchor doesn\'t have visible children."'

column10: b'b" Thank you for opening an issue. While you are correct that the behavior may be unexpected
column11: the selector is working as documented. While the behavior differs between Firefox and Chrome
column12: Chrome reports zero width and zero height
column13: which technically means it is not visible according to our docs...The fact the hidden elements can have visible content can seem strange
column14: but it\'s the way it is in Chrome. But more importantly
column15: the cost of working around this would be far greater than we are willing to deal with. I don\'t think this is the only edge case where the selector behaves in a way that can be unexpected
column16: but I would prefer to keep the selector as simple as possible and let the edge cases be covered by other means."'

column10: b"b' @timmywil so most of this issue discussion has been about the change to because i thought the changes in the first part of my opening comment about returning undefined on hidden or detached elements was in tests only. However i was wrong and i think this has more potential to break things in userland then the change for how is handled.  This comes up in ui and mobile quite a bit it turns out. Both jQuery UI and Mobile allow widgets to be instantiated on a default element in a detached state via and also just in general allow instantiating widgets on detached elements for improved performance among other reasons.  There are also many many situations where a widget or other plugin of some sort may be instantiated or called inside of a hidden container. This is a major issue for plugin authors that cant ever reasonably know if they may be inside a hidden container ( think popups panels etc ) or in jQuery Mobile everything is hidden when the page is initialized.  This all means where as in the past you could call on any element with out any worry you now need to always check the return value before using it. So it will make a lot of code go from  to   Who knows it would not surprise me if you start seeing things where is used a lot
column11: doing something like the below to just not have to worry about it.  Because with this change it essentially makes it ( as a plugin author ) never safe to use with out first checking its return value
column12: unless it is in direct response to a user action
column13: that essentially cant happen on hidden or detached elements. for example dragging and mouse interaction type stuff ( this is a case for many of the cases of in ui ) '"

b'b" I\'ve just been looking into an issue whereby if you have a element with the option set and no options selected will return rather than an empty array. If one more more items are selected
column11: then it returns an array. I would have expected that an empty array would have been returned in this case. [This fiddle shows the issue]url  IT appears all the way back to jQuery 1.2 where multiple value support was added. The reason an empty array is not returned is the check for being < 0 [here]url  While I understand that for a single select
column12: I don\'t while get why that would be done for a multi-select. Removing would allow the empty array to be returned. Having said that
column13: I\'m not really expecting this change to be made as I guess a number of sites will depend upon this behaviour. I\'m more wondering if someone might be willing to say why it is done this way? I\'ve searched this issue tracker and the  site
column14: but couldn\'t find any mention of it."'

column10: b"b' It is mentioned in official site of jQuery: url '"

column10: b"b' I am not sure why exatly but i guess they told to use like this: Which is nothing but a short circuit evaluation which is used to set default values! Means you will not have null in that case! Fiddle: url '"

column10: b'b" When you pass a string as the data argument
column11: you need to encode it if the body content-type is using encodeURIComponent. If not (in your case you seem to wanna send json)
column12: then you need to specify the content-type actually is JSON by setting the option to  . The fact jQuery modified the body is incidental. You will have troubles with backends if you don\'t specify a proper content-type and you have special characters in your body (in regard to the encoding) because most backends will attempt to decode the body before any user code can access it."'

column10: b"b' CommonJS: avoid a global with a custom window passed to the factory'"
b'b" In a CommonJS scenario [these lines]url  may result in one of 2 things:1. & exists =2. otherwise
column11: when a custom implementation is passed to the factory: the flag is not passed =I thought for a moment we might want to pass along the second parameter but IMO we should just set it to true in such a case without asking for anything. After all
column12: if someone invokes: then it\'s trivial to attach it to the by ourselves if needed. The fact that we behave differently in CommonJS based on the initial setup worries me."'

column10: b'b" I can provide some history here. Due to url  we concluded that browser emulators in Node need the global set
column11: because while Node has a CommonJS-like environment
column12: the environment in a browser emulator usually does not
column13: and unfortunately some of Node\'s module handling leaked into the emulators. The browserify case is already covered because a window with a document will be present. If the most common use case for requiring jQuery in Node is still to use jQuery within an emulator _and_ if emulators still allow Node\'s module variables to leak in
column14: then I think we should leave it the way it is."'

column10: b'b" We currently have 3 scenarios:1. There\'s no =2. There\'s & exists =3. There\'s & doesn\'t exist =I don\'t like that (2) & (3) diverge. This means that if you do: a global is set but when you do: a global is not set. This just looks like magic. Note that both scenarios may happen when used with browser emulators in Node
column11: I think they should behave in the same way."'

column10: b'b" Not quite. In order to pass scenario 2
column11: you\'d have to do And I would hope no one does that in Node."'

column10: b'b" I actually think we\'re good with what we have."'
b'b" Also
column11: given how finicky changes to the intro have been in the past
column12: I don\'t want to make any changes until someone opens a ticket with a use case."'

column12: open a ticket. And then I\'ve noticed this inconsistency."'

b"b' closest: remove exception for pos selectors'"
b'b" Further discussion here:  url  The documentation for closest states: However
column11: it seems that this is often not the case.  You can see this illustrated here: url  When the context is passed explicitly
column12: closest works as expected and only finds an element if it is within the context element.  However
column13: if the jquery set has a context and closest is called without explicitly passing a context
column14: no context is used (contradicting the documentation).  However

column10: b'b" The context parameter has two effects: a cap on upward traversal
column11: and a root for positional selectors and non-string selectors (another latent bug
column12: by the way). The first is of [arguable value]url  but (as noted above) fails for any element in the collection that does not descend from it
column13: but the second seems utterly pointless ( ? _Really?_) and isn\'t even tested (the closest we have is assertions that [positional selectors _without_ context yield nothing]url  I\'d prefer to drop the parameter completely
column14: but at minimum I think the positional selector interaction should be removed."'

That would  leave only for limiting upward traversal. "'

column10: b"b' Fixing a bug almost always breaks something.'"

b"b' The release notes specify this is a non-breaking change. But you are changing the way the selector syntax works and has worked for a long time. There will be a LOT of code in the wild that uses this construct. Your own test suite previous proved the accepted # syntax:url You had to update it to work with the new syntax. Yet nowhere do you indicate that the selector syntax has now changed. Where is the issue for the bug? Where is the release note stating the change in behaviour?'"

b'b" @cosmicnet Every behavior change may break code that relies on unspecified behavior; if we treated all of them as breaking changes we couldn\'t have non-major releases at all. Semver only applies to what\'s documented
column11: i.e. what\'s on url  We\'ve never promised there that such a selector works
column12: hence by definition changing that is not a breaking change. We did think that it might break some incorrect code
column13: though and that\'s why we didn\'t introduce this change in a patch release but in a minor one
column14: even though semver permits us to do it in a patch release."'

column10: b'b" @cosmicnet specifically what do you think we need to do here? Are you advocating that we revert this change? I don\'t think we can do that. We are trying to parse valid CSS selectors per the spec and allowing these kind of exceptions (even undocumented) makes that difficult if not impossible. It also causes the selector to be rejected by the path which results in performance degradation. If you\'re just saying you\'re frustrated that this was a breaking change to your code
column11: we\'re sorry for that. There were several other undocumented features that we _did_ mention in the release notes
column12: it\'s just hard to know which ones the world may be depending upon. We\'re always glad to take feedback on our WIP builds
column13: note that this was committed long ago and using the WIP build would have revealed the compatibility issue."'

column11: I also see that as documenting the feature. After all
column12: the test suite should be the definitive definition of what is valid and what is not. If it\\\'s proving "undocumented features" that are erroneous then that indicates a serious problem with the tests. I fail to see how not mentioning it at all in the release notes is anything other than an omission. Instead
column13: at the very least a note with the explanation you have given would be far more appropriate.\''

column10: b'b" To put all the discussion in one place
column11: I agree with @danieliser that it is too late to change at this point. The original change was made to master last year and it was shipped in early January. The reason it has resurrected this week is because Wordpress did an update
column12: some Wordpress themes were impacted
column13: and there appears to be no auto-update for themes. Had any of this come to light last year or even right after the 1.12.0 release we could have done something different
column14: but let\'s not revisit this change now. Better to have people update their themes. The going-forward question is how Wordpress will ever update to jQuery 3.0. Right now WP includes both 1.12.x and Migrate 1.x in order to let themes be sloppy.  If they were to upgrade to jQuery 3.0 the themes would need to be able to run with jQuery 1.12 _without_ Migrate before a jQuery3+Migrate3 combination would allow them to work. Given all the uproar about changing an invalid undocumented thing like unquoted attributes I worry how something more substantial will fare. Seems like the main problem is that Wordpress themes are either not being updated by the users or no theme update is available
column15: either of which makes a jQuery update risky. Not sure how to deal with that other than never updating jQuery."'

column10: b"b' Could they just stop auto-updating jQuery and let theme builders decide which version of jQuery to use?'"
b"b' There is always a revert and release this thing in major
column11: not saying that is what we should do
column12: just saying this is an option'"

column10: b'b" Just my 2c here: It seems the main problem is that jQuery throws an error that
column11: if not caught
column12: makes all scripts in the page stop working. jQuery has historically been treating wrong inputs as noop
column13: returning an empty list instead of throwing. That is assumed by the consumers as an implicit behavior inherent from jQuery philosophy. Therefore not many people bothered in surrounding anything in a  clause. A minor update is not expected to break everything. For that reason
column14: any fix that changes the behavior from noop to throw an Error will have a higher impact than a fix that breaks a behavior but doesn\'t stops all scripts in the page. My suggestion in the future to prevent this kind of problem is to treat any behavior change from noop to Error as a major breaking change worth changelog
column15: even if it is not undocumented. This way there will be no unintended breakage. I hope it makes sense."'

Due to the way jQuery gets updated on  sites (via a WP update and not an explicit decision to update jQuery by the site owner) we hadn\'t gotten much feedback about the scale of the problem until last week\'s WP update.Major is a great place for a breaking change if this is considered one

column11: they can do that. But there are 2 ways to do it
column12: WP uses an asset queing system (see wp_enqueue_script). It allows for dynamic inclusion of scripts from themes and plugins including dependency management. IE my plugin uses jQuery so I can tell WP to load it before mine. So if a theme needs an older version they are either replacing it for every script that needed jquery. The alternative would be them enqueing a custom version of jquery separately and using noConflct. @gibson042 That may be a bit presumptuous. WP Core philosophies are a bit different than yours of course

I\\\'m now idling in both the jquery and jquery-dev rooms as jorbin." But idling is not the same as paying attention to everything that\\\'s going on. I\\\'m not saying that this is bad, it\\\'s exactly what I\\\'ve been doing for the jQuery -I\\\'m all for increasing communication even more. Scale of it, however, was revealed only in this ticket, that is why it was re-open and added back to the agenda of the weekly meeting. In monday, we had extensive discussion on not letting these kind of issues rise again in patch and minor versions, which resulted in guideline changes.  So from now on, we will be more careful with these kind of changes and even though they will still be evaluated on case by case basis (as guideline says), likelihood of such event should be very low. Not only for the wordpress themes though but for all users. Maybe @dmethvin or @timmywil have more info about this."'

column10: b'b" But why getter does actually create data object? What\'s the reason?"'
b'b" Because the with no args is defined to return the data object. If one isn\'t there
column11: it creates one
column12: attaches it to the element
column13: and returns that new empty object. Ten years ago
column14: the API could have been defined to return or for an element with no data and you would have needed to set a new data item explicitly. That\'s not the way it was defined though
column15: and lots of code no doubt depends on that behavior now. The assumption was that if you were trying to _get_ the full data item you actually wanted to use it
column16: and the current behavior makes that simpler. So was created as a way to see if there was data on an element without creating it
column17: the presumably less common case."'

column11: this wasn\\\'t for IE<9. IE<9 required setting the property to a boolean. I\\\'d like to continue doing this because although browsers may treat any value as true
column12: I like that users can see the value that was set is always a truthy value regardless of what they passed. It is not only forcing values to comply with the spec
column13: but it is educating our users on the fact that even if you set the string "false"
column14: it will still be treated as true. Another helpful side-effect of this has been the ability to tell the difference between a boolean and enumerated attribute quickly. We already consulted the spec for our users.\''

column12: so that we can use to detect the object as any other promise objects if it is returned by possible application initializer callbacks. The current implementation create the jqXHR first as a plain object and use () to patch it with promise apis.  In the pull request I altered the process to be getting an empty Deferred object as jqXHR first and use $.extend() to patch it with the old jqXHR object code. A possible unit test could be as the following: It is quite important for me as an SPA developer for embedded and mobile devices to have the freedom of crafting special customized asynchronize application boot-up sequence. Having jqXHR as true  objects greatly enhance the tidiness of the code especially when mixing $.ajax() calls with other promise based workers. Thanks in advance for considering."'

column10: b'b" The way to get out of this is to adopt ES6 Promise  convert other thenables to ES6 Promise as early as possible when they\'re returned by something. Then deal with ES6 Promise quirks and shortcomings
column11: which are numerous. However
column12: at least the tools and developer knowledge will support those shortcomings better. The changes made in jQuery 3.0 are intended to improve ES6 Promise interoperability as much as we can without breaking five year\'s worth of existing jQuery user code. It\'s v3
column13: I really hope we don\'t try to change in incompatible ways when we can instead just coexist with ES6 Promise."'

column10: b'b" @bluekvirus I did not realize you had a request of me... can you restate it? If you\'re asking about our guarantees
column11: we take pains to ensure that promises allow registering callbacks on Deferred objects but _not_ resolving them. We also guarantee that non-progress callbacks are invoked no more than once
column12: and that Deferred state changes no more than once. And as of jQuery 3.0
column13: we further guarantee that both Deferreds and their promises adhere to Promises/A+
column14: so our is what everyone expects. I did look at implementing inheritance while honoring those guarantees
column15: but decided that the benefit wasn\'t worth the increased file size... especially when considering the inability of to recognize objects from _other_ jQuery instances. The simple fact is that we (i.e.
column16: Javascript developers) already _have_ a means of recognizing promises
column17: even if it has warts: the method. And and even provide a means of getting a thenable from any value. But like it or not
column18: this ship has already sailed."'

column14: and there will be a time when chaotic co-existing backward compatible runtimes are offered by different vendors. Whether or not to have detectable _interfaced_ objects early is entirely up to the lib developers and I do hope the group that\'s leading that era is still jQuery. I picked $.Deferred as a start because promise is a well known contract. For the record
column15: after all these years giving me a JS object that I can\'t do whatever I want (freely extend) is unacceptable. But there were times when I did desperately need a lock on the object type to get the guaranteed interfaces. And those moments always challenged my feelings about Javascript. Anyone who wants to go nuts about resolving an ajax call  would probably want to and will not be interfered by the real ajax return resolved by XMLHttpRequest (it might be a reject but based on your description the state changes only once

column10: b'b" Here\'s an abridged summary of what happens for  : * Construct nodes from the HTML text * Identify (and temporarily disable) contained script elements * Insert nodes into the DOM * For each script (in order)
column11: * Re-enable * If in-document and not already evaluated
column12: evaluate  BUT in this case
column13: the first script invokes jQuery UI\'s on an ancestor of later scripts _before_ they are evaluated
column14: which applies DOM manipulation to the ancestor\\xe2\\x80\\x94a process that assumes all in-document script elements have already been evaluated (as is the case for static content) and marks them accordingly. By the time the outer call gets around to looking at the later script
column15: the inner call has already marked it as evaluated
column16: so it is skipped over.  The weight of the code required to fix this issue is probably too great for us to justify adding (especially since script evaluation is an undesirable legacy behavior)
column17: but it can be easily worked around by moving scripts outside the manipulated ancestor: url "'

b'b\' <!-Feature Requests: Please read url  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.  Bug Reports: Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest version of jQuery. Logically
column12: the expression is a no-op. The comment indicates that somebody once saw it cause some side effect in an unspecified version of Safari. For this reason
column13: no lint will pass such a line. This comment confirms that our lint was forced to ignore the transgression.   If a fuse blows
column14: you don\\\'t put tinfoil between the contacts; it\\\'s trying to tell you that something is wrong.  Furthermore
column15: what makes us think that the parent of an will be a  ? Could be an [ ]url As this issue has the potential to foul up form input
column16: it should be given a high priority.  I\\\'ll leave the solution to this one as an exercise for the moment. A solution was given to Resig several years ago and discussed in the old jQuery forum
column17: as well as on Usenet. He mentioned something about not wanting to add an extra line and confirmed that he couldn\\\'t find a browser that "proved" it didn\\\'t work (i.e. show me where it fails). Hint: the no-op line has the answer and discards it. ;)  ### Link to test case ###  No test case. Not known for sure where or when it might fail. Do know that elements without at least one containing a attribute are vulnerable (as that creates an *implicitly* selected  ).  Likely not an issue once the page is loaded
column18: but without reviewing the DOM standards
column19: can\\\'t say for sure when browsers are required to set the property to reflect an implicit selection. Instead of worrying about that (or testing)
column20: let\\\'s just fix the logic.  PS. There is an attempt at a feature test that sets a flag that isn\\\'t checked in relation to the above line
column21: but it is checked in other areas of the code with similar lines:   One problem with that test is that it is testing a *disembodied* and there\\\'s certainly no guarantee that it will pass based on any standard that I know of (again
column22: would have to consult the specifications). So false positives for this "problem" will likely occur
column23: adding additional no-op execution for no reason at all. I know that jQuery is supposed to work with document fragments
column24: but the tested is without even that.  Another problem is it doesn\\\'t test the assumed solution to see if it improves the situation
column25: only that there may be a problem. Again
column26: this will result in no-op execution without any reason to expect it will do anything useful.  A third problem is that the name of the flag ( ) is not very descriptive of what it is supposed to mean. If it wasn\\\'t tacked on to this object
column27: we could make the name as long as we want as the minification process would reduce it. Regardless
column28: saving a few bytes at the expense of clarity is a bad trade (not to mention that HTTP compression will likely end up saving the bytes anyway).  If we just fix the logic for the half dozen related lines then we don\\\'t need this test at all. And BTW
column29: what does "Support: IE <= 11 only" imply? See similar comments throughout and they don\\\'t make a lot of sense to me (e.g. the original hack in this case was for some unspecified Safari version).\''

column10: b"b' .position() and .offsetParent() return incorrect results in FF + recent versions of Chrome'"
b"b' The W3 offsetParent algorithm changed on 9/15. It now includes ancestor elements with a CSS transform applied. Chrome and (maybe?) FF are in compliance with the new spec
column11: while IE and Safari are not. As a result .position() is now returning incorrect results in these browsers.  IMO jQuery will probably need to implement its own ancestor traversal rather than relying on DOM-provided .offsetParent
column12: otherwise results will forever depend on the browser+version of the client.  See: w3-drafts#409'"
