column12: url  doesn\\\'t seem to say anything useful on its own (which is not surprising; rendering is described elsewhere in HTML).  url  describes association of elements with layered shapes on an image
column13: which are not "CSS layout boxes" (not least because they\\\'re not actually box-like in any way; they can have pretty arbitrary shapes).  There\\\'s no SVG involved here
column14: of course.  OK
column15: on to url  which is where HTML describes rendering.  This says
column16: in :  area { display: none; }  (the actual selector includes other things).  Great
column17: that\\\'s something to work with.  url  says: The current css-display draft at url  likewise says: So as far as I can tell the Firefox behavior is exactly following the specs here: elements have no layout boxes
column18: and hence returns an empty list.  @markelog

column10: b'b\' The Firefox thing with returning rects for the _image_ if your ask for them for an _ _ whose imagemap is used by the image is a bug
column11: plain and simple.  See url  for the longstanding issue tracking that problem. As far as I can tell
column12: the specs are pretty clear.  Firefox has a bug in that it sometimes returns rects for elements.  jQuery has a bug if it ever expects rects to be returned for elements.  The specs say that should NOT happen
column13: and in practice it does not happen in Firefox in some cases
column14: and should stop happening in Firefox in all cases once we fix the above-linked issue.  If it\\\'s just jQuery _consumers_ who are implicitly depending on elements having boxes
column15: then that\\\'s their problem
column16: sort of.  But I should note that the behavior of the non-spec  pseudo-class is defined solely by jQuery and that whatever your definition is it\\\'s on you to implement it consistently.  Then again
column17: url  explicitly says that an element with is considered hidden...  Anyway
column18: Chrome just ignores the HTML spec and doesn\\\'t make display:none
column19: which is why you see differnt behavior there.  I just filed url  on them.  Whether you care about normalizing this across browsers is up to you
column20: of course; again the only definition of is "whatever jQuery means".  If you think the specs should change
column21: please file spec issues with your suggestions for what they should say
column22: of course... Yes
column23: this is one reason why the concept of rects for is nonsense!\''

The new changes go in a good direction; there are a few mistakes (you\'ll see most of them yourself if you run unit tests) but it\'d be better to comment on that once you submit a PR. b"b' ### Description ### The file outputs the parameter unescaped
column11: this coupled with a lack of header allows Cross Site Scripting.  Although the script is only *meant* for testing purposes
column12: a Google search reveals that the file has been deployed to several sites across the web; presumably where the entire jquery repository has been cloned.  I believe that adding a header
column13: while not a perfect solution
column14: will help prevent more sites from inadvertently acquiring this vulnerability. '"

column10: b'b" Thanks for opening an issue
column11: but the proper fix here is for users not to host the test files. The ajax tests are about to get a revamp anyway
column12: but I don\'t think it\'s practical to expect all of the tests to be host-able. is not a recommended installation method. By the way
column13: all of our installation methods can be found on the jquery-dist repo\'s README (which in turn is also the jQuery docs on npm). There is an advanced method that involves building jQuery with grunt which does require cloning the repo
column14: but I would expect those advanced users are not the ones hosting tests."'

column10: b'b" @tomnomnom Also note that this is our development repo which has a lot of things that shouldn\'t be cloned into a production environment. There is also url  that contains only the release files. As @timmywil says
column11: only someone doing a custom build should ever need to clone this repo and there\'s no reason for them to expose it on a server.  If you want to provide some other info on what you found you can send it to security (at)  and we can take a look."'

column10: b'b" @dmethvin I\'ve sent an email as suggested
column11: thank you.  I\'m aware that users aren\'t *meant* to clone the repo for deployment
column12: but some of them *have*. IMO it would be better to fix the issue than to rely on users always doing the right thing
column13: because they demonstrably do not."'

column10: b'b" @tomnomnom Removing the file would not fix the issue but only mask it. We can\'t think of a possible XSS for every file we commit to the repo as the whole repository is not designed to be secure when publicly exposed. We\'d rather not pretend we can make it secure
column11: especially that further changes to this repo (like #3744) will introduce more XSS issues for people deploying the whole repo anyway.  There\'s only one way to fix the issue to do it on the sites end by stopping deployment of the whole repository."'

column10: b'b" For the record
column11: I do think we\'d be open to addressing **server** vulnerabilities given we run it publicly in some ways ourselves as well and it\'d be annoying if someone could attack our Jenkins build server through this.  However
column12: client vulnerabilities don\'t apply to the build server. The issue detailed in this report is not in itself a vulnerability. It allows one to echo plain text into a JavaScript file dynamically served from the build server. That is intentional.  In itself
column13: this isn\'t an attack surface given that web browsers don\'t grant cross-origin rights to a foreign script. Loading JavaScript from domain A on a page in domain B runs the same way as if it would run from domain B (think about CDNs)
column14: it doesn\'t provide any cross-origin access to domain A. (Unlike
column15: e.g. cross-origin HTML in an iframe).  If someone were to host on a production server that both 1) isn\'t static
column16: and 2) uses secure cookies on the same domain
column17: it would not pose a threat. It would first require there to be an HTML page on the same server that has actual XSS vector (e.g. something that allows arbitrary HTML injection on that page
column18: which in turn enables the attacker to insert a script tag for  or somehow change the url of an existing script tag)."'

column10: b'b" @Krinkle I\'m afraid that\'s not true; does not set a header
column11: and so is interpreted as by browsers. No other XSS vector is required.  I\'ve hosted here as an example:  Try going to that link in Firefox (Chrome\'s XSS auditor kicks in despite the lack of header
column12: but Firefox\'s does not)."'

column10: b"b' Here is what I see in Edge: ![edge-bug]url  '"
b"b' I thought this was related to [trac-13180]url  (in which we explicitly decided to not jump from the \\\\ instance shadow tree into the host tree during event processing)
column11: and upon investigation it looks like a browser bug. As tested on BrowserStack:  Browser  jQuery event handler invoked? - IE 11 | [SVGElementInstance]url  | [no]url  Edge 38 (EdgeHTML 14) | [SVGElementInstance]url  | [no]url  Edge 40 (EdgeHTML 15) | SVGUseElement | yes **Edge 41 (EdgeHTML 16)** | **SVGRectElement** | **no (\\\\ is not an ancestor)** Chromium 62 | SVGUseElement | yes Firefox 57 | SVGUseElement | yes  Edge is almost certainly wrong. They should probably switch to the  model of targeting the host node
column12: but we could live with them instead reverting to their older behavior of targeting an instance node.'"

column10: b'b" The concept of a shadow tree wasn\'t established at the time

column13: \\\\ can nest)."'

column10: b'b\' So I\\\'ve messed around with your approach and also a few other things. Before I start cleaning up for a PR
column11: just that we are on the same page
column12: I was wondering about the correct test results for some of your tests in the fiddle. What is the correct result for the five "tricky path" tests? My take: since the cash buster parameter is appended to the query string
column13: tricky-path&\\\\_=OLD for instance needs to result in tricky-path&\\\\_OLD?\\\\_=NEW (since there was no question mark in the test URL) What is the correct result for the "tricky query" test? I\\\'d assume the second question mark ought to be escaped (%3F) for the URL to be correct
column14: but what happens if we get this URL? My take: the first question mark starts the query string
column15: and we have name-value pairs there
column16: with = separating names from values. Therefore
column17: the parameter name would be "tricky-query?\\\\_"
column18: and the value would be "OLD". The result should then be "tricky-query?\\\\_=OLD&\\\\_=NEW". In that case
column19: your approach would pass all tests. :-) Alternatively
column20: we could argue that the last question mark starts the query string (the regex can be changed easily to accomodate that)
column21: but that does not seem to be right. \''

column10: b'b"  Right. The table in the [fiddle]url  is all correct
column11: and in fact optimal with the exception that the output from could be instead of  . It is valid to escape question marks in the query component
column12: [but not necessary]url  Correct. Yes
column13: sorry I didn\'t make that clear. A non-percent-encoded question mark is not allowed in the path or any URI earlier component
column14: so by definition the first such character starts the query component."'

column10: b"b' Thanks for the updated reproduction. Reopening.'"
b'b" This behavior is caused by the CSS transition: url And I would say it\'s expected
column11: because the target value of a relative adjustment is determined right away. You set CSS to stretch out height adjustments over time
column12: then set the height
column13: then immediately adjust it before the first animation completes
column14: which makes the adjustment relative to an intermediate value."'

column10: b'b"  There\'s no API to read the final value so we don\'t really have a choice."'

column10: b'b" There are some swarm failures in issues and some that are not. Rather than opening an issue for every failure
column11: we will track them in the meeting agenda with a link to a swarm job. This will give us a history of swarm failures through the meeting notes and have the advantage of being a little less tedious. Also
column12: swarm failures are often more an indication of something wrong with the test rather than something wrong with jQuery Core itself. And
column13: swarm failures are not urgent. They simply must be addressed before a release. Please be assured there\'s no danger of releasing without all greens (or maybe one or two reds that we are absolutely certain do not necessitate a core change as opposed to a test change)."'

b'b" @timmywil I tested the test case code in following browsers on Windows and results are mentioned belowMicrosoft Edge 42 **jQuery outerHeight 100** (elem).height 100 getBoundingClientRect 130 offsetHeight 130 clientHeight 130 scrollHeight 130  Chrome 71 jQuery outerHeight 130 (elem).height 128 getBoundingClientRect 130 offsetHeight 130 clientHeight 130 scrollHeight 130  IE 11 **jQuery outerHeight 130** (elem).height 98 getBoundingClientRect 130 offsetHeight 130 clientHeight 130 scrollHeight 130  Firefox 61 **jQuery outerHeight 100**  (elem).height 100 getBoundingClientRect 130 offsetHeight 100 clientHeight 100 scrollHeight 100  The above mentioned issue with jQuery\'s outerHeight() does not exist  with IE 11 on Windows when I tested it. As you mentioned
column11: Firefox does not take caption height into account while returning offsetHeight.  Also
column12: there are discrepancies in the values returned by getComputedStyle().height in different browsersChrome: getComputedStyle().height does consider caption height and returns 130.  IE: getComputedStyle().height of IE 11 does not consider caption height and also subtracts the border height (-2px) from the rectangles height 100 and returns 98 instead of 100.  Firefox: getComputedStyle().height of Firefox considers only the height of rectangle and returns 100.  Can we open a bug to IE team as getComputedStyle(elem).height returned by IE is different than the other browsers?  Please let me know if Mozilla team is not updating their code and we need a code change for this issue.  Thanks. "'

b'b" We\'ve discussed it today. While it may look surprising that an element may be higher than its set height
column11: its not really isolated behavior. With the default value for specifying a or on an element will cause that behavior already. It turns out tables have similar behavior captions make the table higher than the specified height.  Now
column12: is supposed to cover & (and optionally even  ) but it doesn\'t say anything about  . Also
column13: what if someone really wants the current behavior? Should we introduce a separate flag that will handle  ? This is all introducing complexity for an edge case as captions are way less prevalent than paddings or borders.  Also
column14: as Boris Zbarsky rightly noticed in url  Chrome behavior has an unfortunate behavior where setting to the value returned from the same element with would change its height.  Therefore
column15: it seems we might be closer to accept Firefox behavior. But since the spec seems unclear what\'s desired here and browsers disagree
column16: we wouldn\'t want to end up in a situation where we implement behavior opposite to the one that\'s specced. Until that\'s resolved
column17: we\'re not going to normalize either way."'

column10: b'b\' It seems like the issue the OP is reporting may be due to that Edge does not "fully" set focus to the input element after the page has been reloaded using the browser\\\'s "Refresh" button.  When the page is reloaded using the browser\\\'s "Refresh" button it appears that the document is not given focus
column11: as seen by probing
column12: resulting in some weirdness e.g. the input caret is not in the input element even though the input element reports it has focus.  Nevertheless
column13: I was curious and looked into this a little bit and noticed something
column14: perhaps a bug
column15: in jquery in this particular situation.  It is not necessarily causing the issue the OP reports
column16: but may contribute to some confusion.  I noticed that the value of depends on other calls to  .  In the sample below
column17: (initially) returns  . Then a call to is made and returns (*see below). From then on
column18: the same call to now returns  .  This is due to that two different code paths are taken in jquery depending on whether contains one or more elements.  If contains one element then one code path is taken to determine the value of using the DOM method.  If contains more than one element
column19: a different code path is taken
column20: into Sizzle
column21: and a different way of determining the value of is used.  Unfortunately
column22: those two code paths return different values (for the same element) under some circumstances (in particular for when returns  ).  Furthermore
column23: once the different code path into Sizzle has been taken for an element
column24: then future calls will also take that path
column25: even if contains one element only.  The result is can return one value at one time
column26: and another value later without any changes in focus taking place just because two different methods of calculating the value exist and were used. (*: This is strange by itself from a logic point of view returns when there exists an input element that does have focus as evidenced by returning  .)  Here is the sample that demonstrates this I provide it
column27: not as a fiddle to avoid any iframe issues coming into play
column28: as code you have to save to a file and load in Edge.  \''

column18: as expected if matches more than one element
column19: then returns

column22: call and it will return

column24: call and it will return

column10: b"b'  I am pretty sure no sane browser will try to interprete an 404 response of an script element as JavaScript.  I wrote an php code which has an 404 error and an alert as content. This script is referenced direct via script-element and loaded with jQuery. So this alert should be fired twice. But the alert is only fired when loaded via jQuery. Updated testcase: url '"
b'b" @timmywil We\'re not doing what the browser does. As @HolgerJeromin mentioned
column11: if a browser hits an error page when downloading a script it will display an error message in the console but will not try to evaluate the error page as a script. Meanwhile
column12: we [invoke the converter even for error responses]url  and [the converter calls on the response]url I think it\'s a bug we should fix. Moreover
column13: if the 404 page returns something parseable as JavaScript this may influence the page behavior randomly. Granted
column14: such a response is unlikely but possible so in edge cases
column15: this bug may have important consequences."'

column10: b"b' Yup
column11: that makes sense. I guess the only way the browser would try to execute is if the response code did not match the response content.'"

An even simpler test case: url The issue lies in url  where XML nodes are explicitly excluded from and hence from the special boolean attributes treatment. The commit that introduced it (641ad802111d2dc16ccf4b3721784a6addaf20df) dates back to 2011! It was committed by @timmywil. The jQuery issue it fixes is url @timmywil It\'s not clear to me from that old ticket description why it\'s more important in XML documents to be able to set boolean attribute values to any value than in regular HTML documents. Do you remember the reasons?  From what I understand the original issue wanted to set those attrs on a custom node where they don\'t have special meaning. That could be achieved by changing boolean attrs logic to account for the of an element on which it\'s applied

Since oldIE didn\'t have XHTML semantics it should be safe to not support that case since old code wasn\'t expecting it."'

column10: b'b\' This was 7 years ago so bear with me if I misremember some details. I\\\'ll attempt to explain.  The boolean hook is there both for back-compat-lots of code still out there with that would not work as intended-and compliance with the [standard]url  Not even the strings "true" and "false" are technically allowed.  The point is simply to write valid DOM despite common
column11: predictable misuse of the API.  An attribute in an XML document that happens to have the same name as a boolean attribute
column12: such as does not have any special meaning. The boolean attribute behavior only applies to HTML documents (and even then limited to certain nodeNames as @mgol pointed out).  The original bug wasn\\\'t really related to XML exactly
column13: but it did make me think of this distinction when the user tried to access what looked like boolean attributes on a custom tag. As @mgol said
column14: the attribute on a custom tag has no special meaning or behavior. In the old boolean hook
column15: we used to check the corresponding property to construct a valid return value. In this case
column16: the property of course returned
column17: just as it would in XML
column18: and so it always returned for the attribute value. At some point
column19: we started sharing a lot more attribute code with Sizzle and instead checked the attribute using  . If it returns any value at all
column20: we assume the boolean property is and move on-this is what actually fixed the original bug.  The boolean setter hook remains in place to remove boolean attributes whenever someone tries to set
column21: which as @dmethvin pointed out is an artifact of the old attroperties and far too common and technically incorrect. However
column22: Angular should have been using all along. really makes no sense
column23: semantically. If we were completely aligned with the spec
column24: what we should have done is set the value
column25: which would both be invalid and work as if the value or literally any string value were set instead
column26: because browsers are lenient.  As for what changes to make
column27: I\\\'m not sure. It\\\'s my understanding that boolean attributes also have no special meaning or behavior in a pure XML document (which is different than XML in HTML)
column28: even on tags that happen to be named
column29: hence the different path for XML documents. However
column30: XHTML presents a challenge if we cannot distinguish between XHTML (which is just XML syntax for HTML) and XML (which would display as raw XML if you tried to render it in a browser without defining the method in which to render it). We support retrieving and setting attributes in both cases.\''

column10: b'b" Sizzle has a PR that should address this. XHTML will follow the HTML path and all *should* work as expected
column11: unless anything we haven\'t foreseen comes up
column12: which sometimes happens."'

column10: b"b' $.map() fails with large arrays in \\xd0\\xa1hrome'"

b'b" When a large array is passed as an argument to we get an error:  RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded  Tested on Chrome **72** for Windows. JQuery version: **3.3.1**  Sample code:  Internally it calls to and crashes there.  As long as I understand
column11: tries to push all elements of the array into the stack before invoking the function and fails on stack shortage.  I believe that any function being invoked thru with a large array as an argument will fail. I\'ve found about 14 usages of in the code of jQuery. I would suggest you to check out all of these cases."'

column10: b'b" Applying to 300
column11: 000 elements isn\'t a use case we\'ve considered. Since we\'re a DOM library
column12: the most common calls relate to arrays of DOM elements and it\'s not common to have that many DOM elements. Are there situations where the internal uses might be passed hundreds of thousands of elements?  In an earlier ticket you mentioned that this happened with a templating library. Instead of processing one big template perhaps you could process multiple templates in groups. "'

column10: b'b" Well
column11: in fact I\'ve just got an error with 130
column12: 000 items...  Why do you think that it is uncommon? Someone could develop an intranet business application that work with large tables. A table easily could have about 6
column13: 500 rows with 10 columns
column14: So you\'ve got 65
column15: 000 cells. Each cell could contain two tags
column16: so you\'ve got 130
column17: 000 tags...  Anyway
column18: the documentation doesn\'t mention about any limitations. The function is described like a common use function. The native doesn\'t crash on such arrays
column19: so it is quite unexpected when the jQuery\'s one does. It was not my ticket.  I\'m concerned that the problem is general for jQuery since it uses method internally. So users could have troubles with some other functions
column20: not only  . And they really have (according to some closed issues)."'

column10: b'b" Nobody should be rendering 6
column11: 500 rows on a page simultaneously. That is a good case for pagination or other segmentation techniques like a virtual scrolling window. There are certainly occasional tickets where people hit these limits in jQuery
column12: but as far as I can recall they have all been in this category of use cases that are unsupported  inadvisable. It\'s not a limitation in jQuery
column13: it\'s in Chrome. Firefox works up to at least 500
column14: 000. There\'s got to be a limit *somewhere* and using a design that hits a rarely-hit limit probably means you\'re pushing the limits in inadvisable ways."'

column10: b'b" I wouldn\'t be opposed to using native when available in the current browser _if that doesn\'t increase the bundle too much_. We\'d have to create an internal function that would defer to when available and to when not available and use it consistently around the code base. It might even be faster than our implementation
column11: who knows?  This wouldn\'t help in IE (and [Edge]url  but that will change soon) by default but: 1. Some apps don\'t support IE. 1. Some apps provide polyfill for new APIs; if their polyfill doesn\'t suffer from the limitation that using does
column12: it\'d work even there.  I\'ll reopen so that we can discuss it a little more."'

b'b\' As @dsandber observed
column11: the source text occurs [only once]url  in jQuery
column12: in a context like this:   comes from [leverageNative]url  as either "click"
column13: focus
column14: or "blur"
column15: and is a [Data]url  map that _should_ be library-internal but is actually exposed to consumer code via [ ]url We expect to be fully under the control of leverageNative
column16: and thus either or an array of trigger data set in outermost event handling. But if some _other_ code is using to set e.g. "focus" data to a non non-array value
column17: then we would see precisely this kind of error\\xe2\\x80\\x94and I strongly suspect that\\\'s what\\\'s going on. We [specifically addressed this point]url  before landing the new code
column18: but obviously can only protect against _internal_ collisions rather than external.  We need to decide whether to rename the private data key or leave this as a purely consumer issue. Can everyone experiencing problems please find the use of that messes with "focus"  "blur"  "click"?\''

column10: b'b" Thanks so much @fancyapps
column11: this is real and I feel pretty dumb right now. The issue is that in environments where native  are async
column12: the leverageNative native event handling still sets private data
column13: which results in an error on the _next_ triggered invocation: url I think a fix needs to update detection of outer synthetic events to use not just but also absence of sentinel data that can never be returned by the in native event handling. Before optimizing for size
column14: I\'m thinking something like url  (in which the lines demonstrate prepending itself to the saved array for this purpose).  And I also noticed in passing that the  setup and trigger handlers call every time rather than guarding it with a call as the click setup and trigger handler do
column15: so we should fix that as well to avoid unbounded addition of handlers."'
